content.description:
Start just left of the ramp that separates the shorter climbs on Hemingway Right from the longer ones. Follow the bolts through some thought provoking moves for the grade.

Farthest right bolt line that starts in the creek bed. (Routes farther right start off the forest floor)
8 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Easy short climb up the right leaning semi circular flake past a couple bolts to a big ledge with chains.

Start up the obvious flake near the right side of the wall.
3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

A direct start to Farewell to Arms adds a hard boulder problem off the deck to gain a jug rail before joining Farewell at the horizontal rail. 

5 bolts

A roped boulder problem- 

Start from the small ledge shared by "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Kilimanjaro" using the left facing side-pull under the expansion bolts (the glue-ins up the yellow streak are for Kilimanjaro). 

Use delicate footwork, balance, and sharp holds to get you through a boulder protected by the first 2 bolts. The climbing eases after, including a good rest typical of the horizontal fracture high on Hemmingway left. From the ledge, one more bolt protects the final tricky bit of climbing - height is an advantage here!



4th line from the left. 3 climbs go up the incredibly blank face, 2 of which have glue in bolts. This is the rightmost of these 3 lines (expansion bolts).

4 bolts, drop in anchor

Easy climbing to a large break in the rock to ponder the intricate sidepull crux sequence, more easy climbing above. 

Start at left trending ramp
5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Solid feet and decent hands will bring you success here. Relatively short and well protected route, good for newer leaders.



Located on the small outcrop wall on the farthest left side of the Hemingway Wall


Bolted Protection (4)

Smooth, well protected climbing with good holds and feet placements. Great short lead for new leaders (or good TR for new climbers)



The right of two bolt lines on the small outcrop wall on the farthest left side of Hemingway wall

3 Bolts to a bolted anchor

Slabby start due to the flooding moving into fun climbing through some bulges on the arete.  

The bolted arete mid-way through Hemingway wall.

bolts (4)

One of the more popular routes on the wall. Start with polished feet and awkard moves to gain a good jug for the first bolt, crank past not great hands via the diagonal crack and no good rest stances to a stemming crux. Push past the crux to easy climbing to the finish.

Middle of Hemingway wall with the distinct left trending diagonal crack that terminates at a broken right facing corner.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Sketchy start up the glass polished post flood exposed rock gets you to the high first bolt. Crank up some strenuous moves past another bolt to the technical crux on the absolutely bare slab finish.

The first bolt line in the middle of the Hemingway Wall that is significantly shorter than the climbs to its left. There are 3 other anchors on the same level to the right of Grey Matter.
3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

A old-school testpiece, and the first 5.12 in the Bow Valley. Rarely onsighted. 

Earnest starts off a small ledge and is instantly in your face, with consistently hard technical climbing for several bolts. A large rest awaits after the opening crux, but it's not over yet. 

Stick clipping the first bolt (or two!) is recommended.

6 bolts

Climb the corner using good jams up to a chock stone. From there, veer left and finish on the last bolts of Zipcode. 



The big right facing corner at the right end of Hemingway wall.

BD 1, 2 and 3 and two quickdraws.

Tricky technical climbing between the first and second bolts leads to significantly easier climbing above as this route merges with the third bolt and anchor of Cakewalk



Starts just right of 'Cakewalk'. Climbs up and left (merges with Cakewalk on the third bolt) to a bolted anchor just above and left of a tree growing and curling out away from the rock.

Three bolts to a bolted anchor

Nice climbing up a left-trending crack. Crux near the top where there is a shorter section of slab with limited holds. Goes relatively easy for the grade.



Farthest right route on Hemingway Wall. Go up and into the trees at the far right side of Hemingway and find the left-trending crack towards the far right side of the wall.

Bolts (7) + Bolted Anchors

Start just left of Success Pool (5.12a). A hard move getting to the second bolt leads to easier climbing and a shared rest with Tropicana (5.12d). From here, a difficult traverse right leads to a quick shake and an implausible reach move to a sloper before testing your endurance to the chains.

Quite hard. 

Stick clip the first bolt

6 bolts

Fun slab/face climbing.

Right side of Hemingway Wall slightly up from the stream. 
Bolts with chain anchor at the top of the cliff

On the far left of the main Hemingway Wall face. While a little easier than most of the routes on Hemingway, this route is worth doing and a good intro into the technical style of Hemingway. Start easily up a broken corner to a slabby face with small edges. 

9 bolts.

A slippery start gets you into good under clings and bad feet with an early crux. Easier climbing trending slightly right gets you to the anchor.



4 bolted line from the big corner crack separating Hemingway wall. 

4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Climb the corner flake the entire way up, keeping your feet opposed to minimize pump on the arms



Climb the right-facing corner (that is a smaller corner and located right of another larger corner)

Bolted

Climb the first 3 bolts of Farewell to Arms, but instead of following the leaning crack left, boldly climb straight up the face. Impeccable rock,  intricate and fun moves, and just a touch of spice have made this an instant classic.  

A direct finish to Farewell to Arms. 
5 bolts.

Start in front of the cluster of trees and follow the bolt line up and left to a high slabby crux after the last bolt. Anchor on the left. On the far right side of Hemingway Wall, in the treed area. Route starts in front of a cluster of trees right next to the wall.

7 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Follow the left facing corner to a high bolt or start left on some thin slabby moves to gain the overhang and traverse to the first bolt. Pull past the roof onto very thin moves on the face (crux) followed by an easy diagonal crack to the chains.

Start under the obvious left facing corner and overhang that is immediately next to the dirt ramp separating the ~10m Hemingway Wall Right climbs from the longer climbs on the right.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor with a permabeaner.

A high first bolt above water smooth slab gets you into some technical movement. After the second bolt (use a longer draw or extend it) cut right and look for a third one directly under a horizontal pinch. If you continue straight up along the glue ins you will be on Walk on the Wild  Side 5.11c

A fun technical crux at the last bolt gets you to the anchor. Fantastic route and definitely worth doing!



5th bolted line left of the big corner that splits Hemingway Wall.

6 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Climb the slippery slab into a dihedral with a massive jug block. Climb through a fun bulge to another rest in a crack, then exit by traversing out right. 

A direct finish avoiding the final traverse by making a spooky mantle raises the grade to 5.12b. 

Bolts

This line heads straight up from the last bolt of "Success Pool" to the alternate anchors. 

Start with the demoralizing water-worn slab characteristic of Grotto to a high first clip (stick clip/pre-hanging the draw recommended). Traverse right on good holds until you can hike a foot and pull back left into the smooth dihedral where you a greeted by buckets, and a mega block. Break right using a bit of body tension and some big moves on good holds to clear the "Success Pool" crux boulder and reach a handrail ledge. 

Continue slightly right to the left slanting crack, and follow this straight up to the anchors pulling one more boulder involving a pinch and an obnoxiously high foot to get you the grade.



Middle-Right of Hemingway Wall, look for a dihedral with a heavily chalked block in it ~7 m off the ground, and a left leaning crack starting ~12 m off the ground. 

6 bolts, rap rings.

A linkup of Tropicana into Running out of Room.

Climb the opening boulder problem of Tropicana, then at the third bolt climb a hard boulder problem leftwards into Running out of Room. Unfortunately now you have to do the entire crux of Running out of Room. Good luck!

Back cleaning the third bolt of Tropicana may be helpful


Bolts

Starts with a hard boulder problem off the deck. Climb through easier terrain to a good shake before the crux, a baffling boulder problem. Stick the move to the sloper and run it out to the chains. To climb this route you need to be a technical climbing wizard, or have extremely strong fingers, or preferably, both.

Stick clipping the first bolt or two is recommended. 

Bolts

Follows a prominent left leaning weakness- a very natural line other than the shenanigans you have to clear the opening slab!

Start up the water-worn slab to a high first bolt (previous generation glue-in with a narrow hole, stick clip recommended). Pull a tricky sequence to leave the under-cling at the top of the water-worn section to gain the face which has holds, and friction. Trend slightly left using good holds (and smart body position) until you reach a final rest stance in the top crack with a pseudo ring lock and a back 3 pocket. Take the opportunity to shout down to your belayer about how cool your holds are.

Intermittently layback the crack, clipping your last bolt to the right (just right of the crack). Traverse hard right on the sloping, and then not so sloping hand rail using a combination of real, and partially imaginary feet. Keep it cool and rock up onto the hand rail to clip the chains!

Alternatively, continue straight up from the crack pulling a nasty pinch/mantle to the alternate chains on the left for a more desperate finish (5.12a)



Head for the right end of Hemingway Wall. This bolt line starts directly below the high arete/just left of the black streak (second bottom bolt from the right). Look for the left slanting weakness, and the especially prominent left leaning crack up high (~12 m). Shared start with "Stone Age Romeo's.

6(?) bolts, cold-shut

climbs.name: Walk on the Wilde Side (Alternative Finish)

content.description:
Climb the prominent left leaning weakness of "Walk on the Wilde Side" all the way until it ends, then go straight up! 

After you pull the final boulder (shared by "Success Pool Direct"), it's probably easiest to step to the right and clip the normal "Walk on the Wilde Side" anchors to retrieve your draws. 



Start as for "Walk on the Wilde Side" and go straight up at the top (no rightward traverse)

6 bolts, rings.

Climb a fun flake just to the right of the bolts



Bolts are located just to the left of the obvious flake running up and right.

Bolted Protection

Climb follows the arete of the largest most obvious right-facing corner on Hemingway wall. Climb the fin feature half way up which provides excellent holds on top and good footing once you can stand to it.



Start on the arete just left of the largest right-facing corner on the wall. Clip bolts on your right as you ascend the arete.

4 Bolts and bolted anchor

Quality rock that catches sun in the mornings. Primarily bolted.

Erosion at the base of the wall, especially on the right side, has left the first bolt extremely high on some routes. Compounded by the highly smooth and polished rock in these areas, a stick clip is highly advised!
